questions.text: Which of the following is best serological marker of acute CMV infection in a pregnant woman? [Twisted PYQ]

options.label: A
options.text: High levels of CMV IgG with high avidity

options.label: B
options.text: Presence of CMV IgM with low avidity IgG

options.label: D
options.text: High avidity IgG with negative IgM

questions.correct_answer: B. Presence of CMV IgM with low avidity IgG
questions.explanation:
Ans. B. Presence of CMV IgM with low avidity IgG

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • In acute CMV infection, the presence of CMV IgM antibodies along with low avidity IgG is the most reliable indicator. Low avidity IgG indicates recent infection as antibodies haven't yet matured to high binding strength, which typically takes 2-4 months. When combined with positive IgM, this strongly suggests acute primary infection.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. High levels of CMV IgG with high avidity: High avidity IgG indicates past infection, not acute infection, as antibodies have already matured to strong binding strength.
  • • Option A. High levels of CMV IgG with high avidity:
  • • Option C. Presence of CMV IgG alone: CMV IgG alone only indicates past exposure to CMV and doesn't differentiate between acute or past infection.
  • • Option C. Presence of CMV IgG alone:
  • • Option D. High avidity IgG with negative IgM: This pattern typically indicates past infection with no current reactivation or acute infection.
  • • Option D. High avidity IgG with negative IgM:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The combination of CMV IgM positivity and low avidity IgG provides the strongest evidence for acute primary CMV infection, which is particularly important in pregnant women due to risk of congenital transmission.

questions.text: Identify the structures in the given image. (NEET PG 2024)

options.label: A
options.text: A – Apocrine sweat gland, B – Arrector pilorum, C – Eccrine sweat gland, D – Sebaceous gland

options.label: B
options.text: A – Arrector pilorum, B – Apocrine sweat gland, C – Eccrine sweat gland, D – Sebaceous gland

options.label: C
options.text: A – Sebaceous gland, B – Eccrine sweat gland, C – Arrector pilorum, D – Apocrine sweat gland

options.label: D
options.text: A – Eccrine sweat gland, B – Arrector pilorum, C – Sebaceous gland, D – Apocrine sweat gland

questions.correct_answer: D. A – Eccrine sweat gland, B – Arrector pilorum, C – Sebaceous gland, D – Apocrine sweat gland
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Eccrine sweat glands are located closer to the skin surface, arrector pilorum is a small muscle connected to hair follicles, sebaceous glands produce sebum and are linked to hair follicles, while apocrine sweat glands are deeper and secrete a thicker fluid associated with hair follicles.

questions.text: The structure indicated by the black circle in the electron micrograph represents? (Twisted PYQ)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D. Postsynaptic density

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The arrow in the electron micrograph points to the postsynaptic density This appears as an electron-dense thickening of the postsynaptic membrane It contains receptors, ion channels, and scaffolding proteins essential for synaptic transmission The postsynaptic density is a characteristic feature of chemical synapses
  • • The arrow in the electron micrograph points to the postsynaptic density
  • • This appears as an electron-dense thickening of the postsynaptic membrane
  • • It contains receptors, ion channels, and scaffolding proteins essential for synaptic transmission
  • • The postsynaptic density is a characteristic feature of chemical synapses
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Mitochondria:
  • • Option A. Mitochondria:
  • • Mitochondria appear as oval or elongated structures with distinct double membranes They contain visible cristae and a matrix While present in the image, they are not what the arrow indicates
  • • Mitochondria appear as oval or elongated structures with distinct double membranes
  • • They contain visible cristae and a matrix
  • • While present in the image, they are not what the arrow indicates
  • • Option B. Golgi bodies:
  • • Option B. Golgi bodies:
  • • Golgi apparatus appears as stacked, flattened membrane cisternae Often surrounded by small vesicles The structure pointed to lacks the characteristic stack-like appearance of Golgi
  • • Golgi apparatus appears as stacked, flattened membrane cisternae
  • • Often surrounded by small vesicles
  • • The structure pointed to lacks the characteristic stack-like appearance of Golgi
  • • Option C. Synapse:
  • • Option C. Synapse:
  • • While this is a synaptic junction, the arrow specifically points to the postsynaptic density The synapse includes both pre- and postsynaptic elements, synaptic cleft, and associated structures This option is too general for the specific structure indicated
  • • While this is a synaptic junction, the arrow specifically points to the postsynaptic density
  • • The synapse includes both pre- and postsynaptic elements, synaptic cleft, and associated structures
  • • This option is too general for the specific structure indicated

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Ultrastructural features of synapses Identification of specific synaptic components in electron micrographs Distinguishing between different cellular organelles The importance of postsynaptic density in synaptic function
  • ➤ Ultrastructural features of synapses
  • ➤ Identification of specific synaptic components in electron micrographs
  • ➤ Distinguishing between different cellular organelles
  • ➤ The importance of postsynaptic density in synaptic function

questions.text: Which of the following is correct regarding the location of immune responses? [Twisted PYQ]

options.label: A
options.text: Primary response occurs mainly in bone marrow, secondary in lymph nodes

options.label: B
options.text: Primary response occurs in lymph nodes and spleen, secondary in bone marrow and lymph nodes

options.label: C
options.text: Both primary and secondary responses occur mainly in bone marrow

options.label: D
options.text: Both primary and secondary responses occur mainly in lymph nodes

questions.correct_answer: B. Primary response occurs in lymph nodes and spleen, secondary in bone marrow and lymph nodes
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Primary response occurs in lymph nodes and spleen, secondary in bone marrow and lymph nodes

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Understanding anatomical sites of immune responses Primary response: lymph nodes and spleen are main sites Secondary response: bone marrow is the primary site, followed by spleen and lymph nodes Different anatomical locations reflect different cellular mechanisms involved in each response
  • ➤ Understanding anatomical sites of immune responses
  • ➤ Primary response: lymph nodes and spleen are main sites
  • ➤ Secondary response: bone marrow is the primary site, followed by spleen and lymph nodes
  • ➤ Different anatomical locations reflect different cellular mechanisms involved in each response

questions.text: Which of the following organisms is represented by the given form of replication? (INICET MAY 2018)
questions.explanation:

questions.text: What is the most preferred site for the needle insertion into the thoracic cavity for the pleural fluid removal? (FMGE JULY 2023)

options.label: A
options.text: Lower border of the upper rib

options.label: B
options.text: Upper border of the lower rib

options.label: C
options.text: Lower border of the lower rib

questions.correct_answer: B. Upper border of the lower rib
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Upper border of the lower rib

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The most preferred site for needle insertion during a thoracentesis (removal of pleural fluid) is along the upper border of the lower rib within the intercostal space. This is because the neurovascular bundle (vein, artery, and nerve) runs along the lower border of each rib within the costal groove. Inserting the needle at the upper border of the lower rib minimizes the risk of damaging these vital structures.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Lower border of the upper rib: Inserting the needle here would increase the risk of injuring the neurovascular bundle within the costal groove of the upper rib.
  • • Option A. Lower border of the upper rib:
  • • Option C. Lower border of the lower rib: This would also pose a high risk of damaging the neurovascular bundle.
  • • Option C. Lower border of the lower rib:
  • • Option D. Middle of the intercostal space: Inserting the needle here does not provide a safe margin away from the neurovascular structures and could still lead to injury.
  • • Option D. Middle of the intercostal space:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ For thoracentesis, always insert the needle at the upper border of the lower rib in the intercostal space to avoid damaging the neurovascular bundle located in the costal groove of the upper rib.

questions.text: Which congenital deformity is shown in the image? (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Anencephaly, craniorachischisis

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The image shows a congenital deformity characterized by the absence of the cranial vault (anencephaly) and the exposure of the entire spinal cord due to the non-fusion of the neural tube (craniorachischisis).
  • • Anencephaly is a severe congenital condition where a major portion of the brain, skull, and scalp is absent. This occurs due to the failure of the anterior neuropore to close during embryonic development. Craniorachischisis involves the failure of closure of both the anterior and posterior neuropores, leading to the exposure of the brain and spinal cord. The entire neural tube remains open, resulting in severe defects.
  • • Anencephaly is a severe congenital condition where a major portion of the brain, skull, and scalp is absent. This occurs due to the failure of the anterior neuropore to close during embryonic development.
  • • Anencephaly
  • • Craniorachischisis involves the failure of closure of both the anterior and posterior neuropores, leading to the exposure of the brain and spinal cord. The entire neural tube remains open, resulting in severe defects.
  • • Craniorachischisis
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Anencephaly: This option only accounts for the absence of the cranial vault but does not include the exposed spinal cord.
  • • Option A. Anencephaly:
  • • Option C. Meningomyelocele, anencephaly: Meningomyelocele refers to a form of spina bifida where the spinal cord and meninges protrude through a defect in the spine. While the image does show an exposed spinal cord, it is not a localized defect as seen in meningomyelocele.
  • • Option C. Meningomyelocele, anencephaly:
  • • Option D. Spina bifida occulta, anencephaly: Spina bifida occulta is a mild form of spina bifida where the vertebral arches fail to fuse but without protrusion of the spinal contents. The image shows a more severe defect.
  • • Option D. Spina bifida occulta, anencephaly:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Anencephaly with craniorachischisis involves the non-closure of the neural tube, resulting in the absence of the cranial vault and exposure of the spinal cord along its entire length.

questions.text: Which of the following is not true about Japanese encephalitis? ( NEET PG 2020)

options.label: D
options.text: Vaccinating pigs is helpful in disease control

questions.correct_answer: C. Man acts as the reservoir
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Man acts as the reservoir

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Understanding the transmission dynamics of Japanese encephalitis is crucial for implementing effective control measures. While humans can become severely ill from JE, they do not play a significant role in the disease's transmission cycle, emphasizing the importance of controlling mosquito populations and managing amplifier hosts like pigs to reduce the incidence of this potentially deadly disease.

questions.text: A 55-year-old diabetic patient presents with foot pain. On examination, you can easily palpate all foot pulses except for a particular artery. The image shows the correct technique for palpating this absent pulse. Which artery is being examined? (Twisted PYQ)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A. Dorsalis pedis artery

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • In diabetic patients, the dorsalis pedis artery pulse is particularly important to assess as it can be one of the first pulses to become impalpable due to peripheral arterial disease. The dorsalis pedis artery is examined:
  • • On the dorsum of the foot Between the first and second metatarsals Best palpated with patient's foot slightly dorsiflexed Absence in up to 10% of normal population (anatomical variant)
  • • On the dorsum of the foot
  • • Between the first and second metatarsals
  • • Best palpated with patient's foot slightly dorsiflexed
  • • Absence in up to 10% of normal population (anatomical variant)
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option B. Posterior tibial artery:
  • • Option B. Posterior tibial artery:
  • • Palpated posterior to medial malleolus Usually remains palpable even in early peripheral vascular disease More consistent anatomically than dorsalis pedis
  • • Palpated posterior to medial malleolus
  • • Usually remains palpable even in early peripheral vascular disease
  • • More consistent anatomically than dorsalis pedis
  • • Option C. Popliteal artery:
  • • Option C. Popliteal artery:
  • • Palpated in popliteal fossa with knee flexed Deep location makes it difficult to palpate normally Not commonly affected in isolation in peripheral arterial disease
  • • Palpated in popliteal fossa with knee flexed
  • • Deep location makes it difficult to palpate normally
  • • Not commonly affected in isolation in peripheral arterial disease
  • • Option D. Perforating peroneal artery:
  • • Option D. Perforating peroneal artery:
  • • Not routinely palpated in clinical examination Branch of peroneal artery Too small for clinical pulse assessment
  • • Not routinely palpated in clinical examination
  • • Branch of peroneal artery
  • • Too small for clinical pulse assessment

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Proper technique for dorsalis pedis pulse examination is crucial in:
  • ➤ Assessing peripheral vascular disease Diabetic foot evaluation Pre-operative assessment
  • ➤ Assessing peripheral vascular disease
  • ➤ Diabetic foot evaluation
  • ➤ Pre-operative assessment
  • ➤ Differentiating between anatomical variation and pathological absence The dorsalis pedis pulse is particularly important in diabetic patients as its absence may be the first sign of peripheral arterial disease

  • • Lateral pterygoid not involved in elevation
  • • Important in biting and chewing
  • • Option C. Depression:
  • • Option C. Depression:
  • • Mainly performed by digastric, mylohyoid, and geniohyoid Opens the mouth Lateral pterygoid relaxes during depression Gravity assists this movement
  • • Mainly performed by digastric, mylohyoid, and geniohyoid
  • • Opens the mouth
  • • Lateral pterygoid relaxes during depression
  • • Gravity assists this movement
  • • Option D. Retraction:
  • • Option D. Retraction:
  • • Performed by posterior fibers of temporalis Posterior digastric assists Moves mandible posteriorly Lateral pterygoid actually antagonizes this movement
  • • Performed by posterior fibers of temporalis
  • • Posterior digastric assists
  • • Moves mandible posteriorly
  • • Lateral pterygoid actually antagonizes this movement

questions.text: Patients with which of the following conditions are more susceptible to infections caused by catalase-positive organisms: (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Chronic granulomatous disease

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Chronic Granulomatous Disease (CGD) is an immunodeficiency disorder that makes patients particularly susceptible to infections by catalase-positive organisms due to a defect in the NADPH oxidase enzyme in phagocytes.

questions.text: The marked structure (mammillary body) is a part of which anatomical circuit involved in memory formation? (Twisted PYQ)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B. Papez circuit

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The mammillary bodies are key components of the Papez circuit, which is crucial for memory formation and emotional processing. The Papez circuit follows this sequence:
  • • Hippocampus → Fornix → Mammillary bodies → Mammillothalamic tract → Anterior thalamic nucleus → Cingulate gyrus → Parahippocampal gyrus → Hippocampus
  • • Hippocampus → Fornix → Mammillary bodies → Mammillothalamic tract → Anterior thalamic nucleus → Cingulate gyrus → Parahippocampal gyrus → Hippocampus
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Yakovlev circuit : This circuit is involved in emotional behavior and includes the orbitofrontal cortex, anterior temporal lobe, amygdala, and anterior insula. While it deals with emotion, it doesn't primarily involve the mammillary bodies.
  • • Option A. Yakovlev circuit
  • • Option C. Basal ganglia circuit : This circuit involves the striatum, globus pallidus, substantia nigra, and subthalamic nucleus. It's primarily involved in motor control and learning, not memory formation through mammillary bodies.
  • • Option C. Basal ganglia circuit
  • • Option D. Meyers loop : This refers to the anterior loop of the visual radiations as they course from the lateral geniculate body to the visual cortex. It's not a circuit but rather a specific anatomical pathway for visual processing.
  • • Option D. Meyers loop

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The role of mammillary bodies in the Papez circuit is crucial for comprehending memory formation and emotional processing. The Papez circuit was one of the first circuits proposed to explain emotional processing in the brain, and while our understanding has evolved, it remains fundamental to understanding limbic system connectivity.

questions.text: Which of the following staphylococcal infections is not toxin mediated? (INICET NOV 2017)

questions.text: A patient presents with fluent but nonsensical speech and has significant difficulty understanding spoken language, although their speech production remains intact. What area of the brain has been damaged in this patient? (Twisted PYQ)
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The patient's symptoms are indicative of Wernicke's aphasia , which is characterized by fluent but nonsensical speech and impaired language comprehension. Wernicke's area (typically located in the posterior part of the superior temporal gyrus in the dominant hemisphere, usually the left) is essential for language comprehension. Damage to this area disrupts the ability to understand spoken language, leading to fluent but meaningless speech output.
  • • Wernicke's aphasia
  • • Wernicke's area
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Broca's area : Responsible for speech production and grammar. Damage here leads to expressive or non-fluent aphasia , where patients struggle to form words and construct sentences but generally understand language. Option C. Heschl's gyrus : Located in the primary auditory cortex, it is involved in processing auditory information. Damage to this area would impair sound perception rather than language comprehension. Option D. Striate area : Also known as the primary visual cortex, it is responsible for processing visual information. Damage to this area can lead to visual deficits but does not directly affect language functions.
  • • Option A. Broca's area : Responsible for speech production and grammar. Damage here leads to expressive or non-fluent aphasia , where patients struggle to form words and construct sentences but generally understand language.
  • • Option A. Broca's area
  • • expressive or non-fluent aphasia
  • • Option C. Heschl's gyrus : Located in the primary auditory cortex, it is involved in processing auditory information. Damage to this area would impair sound perception rather than language comprehension.
  • • Option C. Heschl's gyrus
  • • Option D. Striate area : Also known as the primary visual cortex, it is responsible for processing visual information. Damage to this area can lead to visual deficits but does not directly affect language functions.
  • • Option D. Striate area
  • • Educational objective:
  • • Educational objective:
  • • Damage to Wernicke's area results in receptive aphasia, where patients maintain fluent speech but have significant impairments in understanding language and producing meaningful communication.

questions.text: Which of the following vaccinations are specifically recommended during pregnancy according to standard guidelines? [Twisted PYQ] Influenza (inactivated) Tdap Live attenuated vaccines HPV
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) 1, 2

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Only inactivated or toxoid vaccines are safe during pregnancy Timing of Tdap is crucial for maternal antibody transfer Live vaccines pose theoretical risks to fetus
  • ➤ Only inactivated or toxoid vaccines are safe during pregnancy
  • ➤ Timing of Tdap is crucial for maternal antibody transfer
  • ➤ Live vaccines pose theoretical risks to fetus
  • ➤ Pregnancy is temporary contraindication for certain vaccines

questions.text: Epithelial lining of trachea is made of which type of cells? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Pseudostratified ciliated columnar cells

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The trachea is lined with pseudostratified ciliated columnar epithelium, which plays a critical role in trapping and moving particles out of the respiratory system to keep the airways clear.

questions.text: Which structure develops from the 6th pharyngeal arch artery on the left side? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Ductus arteriosus

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The ductus arteriosus, a critical structure in fetal circulation, develops from the distal part of the 6th pharyngeal arch artery on the left side.

questions.text: Marked structure is derived from the?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A. Endocardial cushions

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The interventricular septum's membranous portion is the indicated structure. It comes from the endocardial cushions.
  • • Endocardial cushions are soft tissue masses that protrude in the atrioventricular and conotruncal regions. Atrioventricular cushions are derived from overlying endocardial cells. The conotruncal cushions are derived from the neural crest cells.
  • • Endocardial cushions are soft tissue masses that protrude in the atrioventricular and conotruncal regions. Atrioventricular cushions are derived from overlying endocardial cells. The conotruncal cushions are derived from the neural crest cells.
  • • Atrioventricular cushions are derived from overlying endocardial cells. The conotruncal cushions are derived from the neural crest cells.
  • • Atrioventricular cushions are derived from overlying endocardial cells.
  • • The conotruncal cushions are derived from the neural crest cells.
  • • Other Options :
  • • Other Options :
  • • Option B. Septum primum: The septum primum is involved in the development of the atrial septum, not the interventricular septum. It forms a temporary structure in the embryonic heart that helps separate the atria.
  • • Option B. Septum primum:
  • • Option C. Left venous valve: The left venous valve is not directly involved in the formation of the interventricular septum. It is a structure found within the embryonic heart that helps direct oxygenated blood from the left atrium into the left ventricle.
  • • Option C. Left venous valve:
  • • Option D. Bulbous venosus: The bulbous venosus is an embryonic structure that contributes to the formation of the smooth part of the right ventricle. It is not associated with the development of the interventricular septum.
  • • Option D. Bulbous venosus:
  • • Cardiac abnormalities, such as ASs, VSDs, and anomalies affecting the major arteries, can be caused by errors in the creation of the endocardial cushion (transposition of the great vessels, common truncus arterious, and tetralogy of Fallot).

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Endocardial cushions contribute to the formation of:
  • ➤ Atrial septa Ventricular septa (membranous portion) Atrioventricular canals Atrioventricular valves
  • ➤ Atrial septa
  • ➤ Ventricular septa (membranous portion)
  • ➤ Atrioventricular canals
  • ➤ Atrioventricular valves
  • ➤ The membranous portion of the interventricular septum develops from the endocardial cushions.

questions.text: The primary lymphoid organ is: (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Thymus

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The thymus is a primary lymphoid organ responsible for the maturation of T cells. It plays a critical role in the development of the immune system.

questions.text: A patient suspected of having acute brucellosis had a serum sample sent for a standard agglutination test. The test was strongly positive initially but became negative after serial dilutions of the serum sample. Which of the following best explains this observation? (Twisted PYQ)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Post-zone phenomenon

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The post-zone phenomenon demonstrates how excess antigen can affect serological testing, producing initially positive results that become negative upon dilution. This emphasizes the importance of understanding antigen-antibody ratios in diagnostic testing and interpretation of serological results.

questions.text: Which of the following disease has the highest mortality once clinically manifested? (INICET NOV 2020)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Rabies

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Rabies has the highest mortality rate once clinical symptoms appear, making it virtually 100% fatal without immediate post-exposure prophylaxis.

questions.text: What is the diagnosis in a child presenting with chorioretinitis, hydrocephalus, and parenchymal calcifications? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Toxoplasma

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The triad of chorioretinitis, hydrocephalus, and parenchymal calcifications is characteristic of congenital toxoplasmosis.

questions.text: A patient presents with urethral discharge. A gram stain smear is made from the discharge sample and the following microscopic image is seen. What is the most likely causative organism? (INICET NOV 2020)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Neisseria gonorrhea

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ The presence of gram-negative, intracellular, kidney-shaped diplococci in urethral discharge is characteristic of Neisseria gonorrhea, a common causative agent of sexually transmitted infections resulting in urethritis.

questions.text: Corticospinal tract crosses the midline at: (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Lower medulla

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The corticospinal tract crosses the midline at the lower medulla in a process known as pyramidal decussation, which is essential for the control of voluntary movements by the opposite side of the brain.

questions.text: Which of the following methods would be most appropriate for determining if a patient has recently recovered from a viral infection? [Twisted PYQ]
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) ELISA (IgG)

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ ELISA is optimal for detecting post-infection antibodies · Real-time PCR measures active viral presence Western blot confirms specific protein presence · Immunoelectrophoresis separates proteins but lacks specificity for viral antibody detection
  • ➤ ELISA is optimal for detecting post-infection antibodies · Real-time PCR measures active viral presence
  • ➤ Western blot confirms specific protein presence · Immunoelectrophoresis separates proteins but lacks specificity for viral antibody detection

questions.text: In which of the following is the disc diffusion method for antibiotic susceptibility testing applied? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Kirby-Bauer method

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The Kirby-Bauer disc diffusion method is a straightforward and widely used technique for assessing bacterial antibiotic susceptibility, providing vital information for the appropriate selection of antibiotics in clinical settings. It is essential for effective antimicrobial stewardship and the management of bacterial infections.

questions.text: A patient presented with an enlarged inguinal lymph node. Which one is the most likely primary cause?( NEET PG 2020 )
questions.explanation:
Ans. B. Anal cancer

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Anal cancer is a primary malignancy associated with the enlargement of inguinal lymph nodes due to its anatomical and lymphatic relationship with the anal canal below the dentate line. Recognizing this link is crucial for correct diagnosis and treatment planning.

questions.text: Bone marrow aspirate of a patient shows the following features. Which of the following is true? ( INICET NOV 2018)

options.label: A
options.text: Buffy coat is used to diagnose the parasite

options.label: B
options.text: It is an obligate extracellular parasite

options.label: D
options.text: Stibogluconate is the first line of treatment in India

questions.correct_answer: A. Buffy coat is used to diagnose the parasite
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Buffy coat is used to diagnose the parasite

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Buffy coat is used to diagnose Leishmania donovani by detecting the amastigote form in intracellular macrophages in patients with visceral leishmaniasis.

questions.text: Which organism moves transcellularly by utilizing actin filaments? (INICET NOV 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Listeria

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • Listeria monocytogenes moves within and between cells by polymerizing host actin filaments, forming "comet tails" that propel the bacterium.
  • • Other Options :
  • • Other Options
  • • Option B. EIEC (Enteroinvasive E. coli) : Invades intestinal cells but does not utilize actin filaments for intracellular movement.
  • • Option B. EIEC
  • • (Enteroinvasive E. coli)
  • • Option C. Salmonella : Invades cells but moves intracellularly via different mechanisms, not actin-based motility.
  • • Option C. Salmonella
  • • Option D. Vibrio : Known for cholera; does not utilize actin for intracellular movement.
  • • Option D. Vibrio

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ Listeria monocytogenes uniquely utilizes actin filaments for intracellular movement, a key feature distinguishing it from other enteric pathogens like EIEC, Salmonella, and Vibrio.

questions.text: A child who is regularly eating outside is presenting with icterus and diarrhea, which of the following infectious agent can spread through the Feco-oral route? (FMGE JANUARY 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Hepatitis A

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Hepatitis A and Hepatitis E spread through the Feco-oral route
  • ➤ Feco-oral route
  • ➤ Transmission of Hepatitis B, C, and D can occur sexually

questions.text: Match the following? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) A-4, B-1, C-2, D-3

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Each infectious disease has a specific staining technique for identification: Malaria (Giemsa stain), Tuberculosis (ZN stain), Leprosy (Fite Faraco stain), and Actinomycosis (Gram stain).

questions.text: All are features of Zika Fever except? (INICET NOV 2017)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Petechial rash

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Zika fever typically presents with a maculopapular rash, conjunctivitis, fever, and arthralgia, and it can be complicated by Guillain-Barre syndrome. Petechial rash is not a common feature and is more indicative of Dengue fever.

questions.text: A woman with recurrent diarrhea is prescribed a broad-spectrum antibiotic. Which of the following is not true regarding Clostridium difficile infection? (NEET PG 2022)

options.label: A
options.text: Oral fidaxomicin is used for treatment

options.label: C
options.text: IgM assay is used to confirm the diagnosis

options.label: D
options.text: Pseudomembrane consists of leukocytes, fibrin, and cellular debris

questions.correct_answer: C. IgM assay is used to confirm the diagnosis
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) IgM assay is used to confirm the diagnosis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Clostridium difficile infection is diagnosed primarily through the detection of toxins rather than IgM assays is crucial for appropriate management. This recognition guides the effective use of specific treatments such as oral fidaxomicin or vancomycin, aimed at countering the effects of these toxins and managing the symptoms of the infection.

questions.text: What is the vector for the condition diagnosed by the image shown below? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Sandfly

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The presence of Leishman-Donovan bodies inside macrophages is indicative of Kala Azar, a severe form of leishmaniasis transmitted by the bite of infected sandflies. Effective prevention and control are critical in endemic regions to reduce the transmission and impact of this disease.

questions.text: An HIV-positive patient presented with complaints of diarrhea and foul-smelling stool. His stool microscopy did not show any ova or eggs, but there was the presence of motile 200 μm larva. Identify the organism. (NEET PG 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Strongyloides stercoralis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Strongyloides stercoralis is diagnosed by the presence of motile larvae in stool, distinguishing it from other helminths that typically show eggs in stool samples.

questions.text: Which of the following is not used as an immediate test in the screening of urinary tract infections (UTI)? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Pour plate culture

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The screening tests for UTI are as follows:
  • ➤ The screening tests for UTI are as follows:
  • ➤ Wet mount examination: It is done to demonstrate pus cells in urine. Leukocyte esterase test: It is a rapid and cheaper method, and detects leukocyte esterases secreted by pus cells present in urine. Nitrate reduction test (Griess test): Nitrate reducing bacteria like E. coli give a positive result. Catalase test: E. coli and other bacteria that produce the enzyme catalase give a positive result.
  • ➤ Wet mount examination: It is done to demonstrate pus cells in urine.
  • ➤ Leukocyte esterase test: It is a rapid and cheaper method, and detects leukocyte esterases secreted by pus cells present in urine.
  • ➤ Nitrate reduction test (Griess test): Nitrate reducing bacteria like E. coli give a positive result.
  • ➤ Catalase test: E. coli and other bacteria that produce the enzyme catalase give a positive result.
  • ➤ Quantitative Culture:
  • ➤ Standardized loop technique Pour plate method
  • ➤ Standardized loop technique
  • ➤ Pour plate method

questions.text: A patient from sub-Saharan Africa presented with fever, anemia, and neurological symptoms. Peripheral smear examination showed pancytopenia. Buffy coat examination revealed trypanosomes with a kinetoplast. What is the vector for the likely disease? (Twisted PYQ)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Tse-Tse fly

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The patient's presentation is suggestive of African trypanosomiasis, also known as sleeping sickness, caused by Trypanosoma brucei. This parasitic infection is transmitted by the bite of an infected tse-tse fly (Glossina species), which is endemic to sub-Saharan Africa. The clinical features include fever, anemia, hepatosplenomegaly, and neurological symptoms such as altered mental status and sleep disturbances. The presence of trypanosomes with a kinetoplast in the buffy coat further supports the diagnosis, as these organisms are characteristic of trypanosomal infections. Early diagnosis and treatment are crucial to prevent progression to the second stage, where the central nervous system becomes involved.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Sandfly: Sandflies are vectors for Leishmaniasis, not trypanosomiasis. Leishmaniasis typically presents with symptoms like fever, weight loss, and hepatosplenomegaly, but it is transmitted by the bite of infected female Phlebotomus sandflies.
  • • Option A. Sandfly:
  • • Option C. Triatomine bug: Triatomine bugs, also known as "kissing bugs," are vectors for Chagas disease (Trypanosoma cruzi), which is primarily found in Latin America. Chagas disease presents with cardiac and gastrointestinal manifestations, differing from the neurological symptoms seen in African trypanosomiasis.
  • • Option C. Triatomine bug:
  • • Option D. Female Anopheles mosquito: Anopheles mosquitoes are vectors for malaria, caused by Plasmodium species. Malaria presents with cyclical fevers, chills, and anemia but does not involve neurological symptoms associated with trypanosomiasis.
  • • Option D. Female Anopheles mosquito:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Understand the epidemiology, clinical presentation, and vector associations of trypanosomal diseases. Recognize that African trypanosomiasis is transmitted by tse-tse flies and presents with systemic and neurological symptoms, distinguishing it from other kinetoplastid infections like Leishmaniasis and Chagas disease.

questions.text: The shown epithelium is seen in: (NEET PG 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Ureter

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Transitional epithelium, marked by umbrella cells and multilayered structure, is primarily found in the urinary tract, including the ureter, where it facilitates expansion and contraction.

questions.text: Which of the following conditions is the causative agent associated with in this case? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Pure red cell aplasia

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Parvovirus B19, the causative agent of erythema infectiosum, is associated with pure red cell aplasia, particularly in individuals with underlying hemolytic disorders.

questions.text: A patient presented with fever, dyspnea, palpitations, and tachycardia. The echocardiography revealed vegetation in the septal leaflets. Tissue sections from them reveal the following findings as shown in the image. What is the most likely implicated agent? (INICET NOV 2021)

options.label: A
options.text: Pigmented septate hyphae at 90 degrees, Mucormycosis

options.label: B
options.text: Right angle branching septate hyphae, Fusarium

options.label: D
options.text: Acute angle branching septate hyphae, Aspergillus

questions.correct_answer: D. Acute angle branching septate hyphae, Aspergillus
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Acute angle branching septate hyphae, Aspergillus

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Aspergillus: Typically seen as septate hyphae with acute angle branching on histological stains such as GMS. Mucor and Rhizopus: Non-septate, broad hyphae with right angle branching, distinguishing them from Aspergillus. Fusarium: Requires culture for definitive identification, although morphologically similar to Aspergillus.
  • ➤ Aspergillus: Typically seen as septate hyphae with acute angle branching on histological stains such as GMS.
  • ➤ Aspergillus:
  • ➤ Mucor and Rhizopus: Non-septate, broad hyphae with right angle branching, distinguishing them from Aspergillus.
  • ➤ Mucor and Rhizopus:
  • ➤ Fusarium: Requires culture for definitive identification, although morphologically similar to Aspergillus.
  • ➤ Fusarium:

questions.text: Which of the following muscles is supplied by the marked nerve? (Twisted PYQ)
questions.correct_answer: C. Both pectoralis major and minor
questions.explanation:
Ans. C. Both pectoralis major and minor

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The medial pectoral nerve (shown in the image) is unique in that it supplies both the pectoralis major and minor muscles. After piercing through the pectoralis minor muscle, it continues to supply branches to the pectoralis major, making it the only nerve that innervates both these muscles.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Serratus anterior : This muscle is innervated by the long thoracic nerve (C5, C6, C7), not the medial pectoral nerve. The long thoracic nerve runs along the lateral thoracic wall and is crucial for scapular stability.
  • • Option A. Serratus anterior
  • • Option B. Pectoralis major only : This is incorrect because while the medial pectoral nerve does supply the pectoralis major, it's not exclusive to it. The lateral pectoral nerve also contributes to pectoralis major innervation, and the medial pectoral nerve additionally supplies pectoralis minor.
  • • Option B. Pectoralis major only
  • • Option D. Latissimus dorsi : This muscle is innervated by the thoracodorsal nerve (C6, C7, C8), which is a branch of the posterior cord of the brachial plexus. The medial pectoral nerve has no role in latissimus dorsi innervation.
  • • Option D. Latissimus dorsi

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Understanding the dual innervation pattern of the medial pectoral nerve to both pectoralis muscles is crucial for surgical procedures in the axillary region and for clinical conditions affecting chest wall movements. This knowledge is particularly important in mastectomy procedures and trauma evaluations of the anterior chest wall.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs is not used for typhoid fever in adults? ( INICET NOV 2018)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Amikacin

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Amikacin is not effective in the treatment of typhoid fever, despite its efficacy in vitro against Salmonella.

questions.text: A 35-year-old urban resident presented with high-grade fever, severe headache, retro-orbital pain, myalgia, thrombocytopenia, and a maculopapular rash. He reports recent travel to a dengue-endemic area and frequent exposure to mosquito bites. What can be the most likely diagnosis? (Twisted PYQ)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Dengue

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Dengue fever is a viral hemorrhagic illness transmitted by Aedes mosquitoes, particularly prevalent in tropical and subtropical regions. The patient's presentation includes high-grade fever, severe headache, retro-orbital pain, myalgia (muscle pain), thrombocytopenia (low platelet count), and a maculopapular rash, which are hallmark features of Dengue infection. The history of recent travel to a dengue-endemic area and frequent mosquito exposure further supports this diagnosis. Retro-orbital pain and thrombocytopenia are particularly characteristic of Dengue, helping to distinguish it from other febrile illnesses.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Malaria: Malaria typically presents with cyclical fevers, chills, sweating, and headache. While thrombocytopenia can occur, retro-orbital pain and a maculopapular rash are not characteristic features. Malaria is more associated with anemia and splenomegaly.
  • • Option A. Malaria:
  • • Option B. Leptospirosis: Leptospirosis presents with high fever, severe headache, myalgia (especially in the calves), conjunctival suffusion, and sometimes jaundice and renal dysfunction in severe cases (Weil's disease). It does not typically present with retro-orbital pain or a maculopapular rash, making it less likely in this scenario.
  • • Option B. Leptospirosis:
  • • Option C. Filariasis: Filariasis is a chronic parasitic infection caused by filarial worms, leading to lymphedema or elephantiasis. It does not present with acute symptoms such as high-grade fever, retro-orbital pain, or thrombocytopenia. Acute presentations are uncommon and typically involve lymphatic inflammation rather than the symptoms described.
  • • Option C. Filariasis:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Recognize the clinical features of Dengue fever, including high-grade fever, retro-orbital pain, myalgia, thrombocytopenia, and rash, especially in patients with relevant exposure history such as travel to endemic areas and mosquito exposure. Differentiating Dengue from other febrile illnesses like Malaria, Leptospirosis, and Filariasis is essential for appropriate diagnosis and management.

questions.text: The structure marked "intra-embryonic body cavity" in the image gives rise to which of the following cavities? (Twisted PYQ)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D. All of the above

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The intra-embryonic body cavity (coelom) divides into three separate cavities: Pericardial cavity: houses the heart Pleural cavities contain the lungs Peritoneal cavity: contains abdominal organs Separation occurs through formation of the septum transversum and pleuropericardial membranes Serious birth malformations, including diaphragmatic hernias, pericardial defects, and lung anomalies, can result from coelomic development.
  • • The intra-embryonic body cavity (coelom) divides into three separate cavities:
  • • Pericardial cavity: houses the heart
  • • Pleural cavities contain the lungs
  • • Peritoneal cavity: contains abdominal organs
  • • Separation occurs through formation of the septum transversum and pleuropericardial membranes
  • • Serious birth malformations, including diaphragmatic hernias, pericardial defects, and lung anomalies, can result from coelomic development.
  • • Option A. Pericardial cavity:
  • • Option A. Pericardial cavity:
  • • Only represents one component of coelom division Doesn't account for other major body cavities Forms earliest but isn't the only derivative
  • • Only represents one component of coelom division
  • • Doesn't account for other major body cavities
  • • Forms earliest but isn't the only derivative
  • • Option B. Peritoneal cavity:
  • • Option B. Peritoneal cavity:
  • • Though largest of coelomic cavities Represents only abdominal component Doesn't include thoracic divisions
  • • Though largest of coelomic cavities
  • • Represents only abdominal component
  • • Doesn't include thoracic divisions
  • • Option C. Pleural cavity:
  • • Option C. Pleural cavity:
  • • Only accounts for lung spaces Represents paired cavities Missing other major subdivisions
  • • Only accounts for lung spaces
  • • Represents paired cavities
  • • Missing other major subdivisions

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Embryological development of body cavities Subdivision of intra-embryonic coelom Relationship between different body cavities Clinical significance of coelomic derivatives
  • ➤ Embryological development of body cavities
  • ➤ Subdivision of intra-embryonic coelom
  • ➤ Relationship between different body cavities
  • ➤ Clinical significance of coelomic derivatives

questions.text: Which among the following is the most specific disease caused by Streptococcus agalactiae?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Neonatal sepsis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Streptococcus agalactiae (Group B Streptococcus) is the most common cause of neonatal sepsis and meningitis.
